This request does not seek the contents of the emails themselves, and only the specified email metadata. Please provide me with the records in an Excel format. I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge and this request is not made for commercial usage. I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Joseph Cox To Whom It May Concern: Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: ### Background ### In 2021, the Boston Globe reported on a series of signs for fake "forced auctions" appearing around the city. The Code Enforcement Division of the Boston Public Works conducted its own investigation, and linked the activity to a company called Global Auctions USA. The article reads, "According to the Boston Public Works Department, its Code Enforcement Division traced the flyers back to a company called Global Auctions USA." You can find the article here: https://www.bostonglobe.com/2021/09/22/metro/what-are-those-strange-forced-auction- signs-appearing-everywhere/ My request concerns records related to this investigation. ### Request ### - All emails between Boston Public Works staff about, related to, or concerning forced auctions from 1st January 2020 to the present. - All emails between Boston Public Works staff about, related to, or concerning "Global Auctions USA" from 1st January 2020 to the present. - Any memos, reports, or files about, related to, or concerning forced auctions from 1st January 2020 to the present. - Any memos, reports, or files about, related to, or concerning "Global Auctions USA" from 1st January 2020 to the present. I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage. I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. Caden pearson Dear Sir/Madam, I'm a reporter from The Epoch Times. I'd like to request confirmation of a recent incident that reportedly took place at the Revere Hotel in Boston. Colman Herman Freelance Reporter This is a public records request for records from Boston Public Schools (BPS). This again is one of those times that a public records request of BPS should have been entirely + unnecessary. 1) On March 13, 2023 — five weeks ago — I made the following request of Max Baker of the BPS press office. I would like to request a telephone interview with Superintendent [Mary] Skipper to discuss sexual misconduct, bullying, and other equity matters at BPS. 2) On March 13, 2023, Mr. Baker responded to me as follows. As for your second point, let me speak to her scheduler and try and get some time on the calendar. Supt. Skipper is pretty busy so it might take some time to schedule. That said, if you provide me with some written questions, I can provide responses to you that come from the superintendent. What is your timeline? 3) On March 13, 2024, I respond to Mr. Baker as follows. I like to stay away from interviews by email. Instead, I like to have contemporaneous discussions that lead to conversational responses and, at the same time, avoid countless back and forth emails. 4) When I did not hear back from Mr. Baker, I wrote the following to him on March 31, 2023. It’s been over two weeks since you said that you would try to arrange an interview for me with Superintendent Skipper. 5) On April 3, 2023, Mr. Baker responded to me as follows. I am still working on that. She is quite busy I'm afraid. 6) On April 3, 2023, I responded to Mr. Baker as follows. Of course Superintendent Skipper is busy. She will alway be busy in her job. I have had difficulty before in arranging to speak with BPS about sexual misconduct. 7) When I did not hear back from Mr. Baker, I wrote the following to him on April 9, 2023. It’s been nearly a month since you told me that you would try to arrange an interview for me with Superintendent Skipper to discuss sexual misconduct, bullying, and other “equity matters.” In that regard I cannot imagine a more important topic for Superintendent Skipper to address. So I want to ask you the status of my request for the interview? 8) When I still did not hear back from Mr. Baker, I wrote the following to him on April 12, 2023. I am following up on the voicemail message that I just left for you, and the email below to which I have not received a response. If Superintended Skipper does not wish to speak with me on the subject of sexual misconduct, bullying. and related “equity” matters, please just tell me that. 9) Mr. Baker remained silent. 10) I would liked to gain an understanding of why Superintendent Skipper has not granted me an interview on the critical matter of sexual misconduct, bullying, and other equity matters at BPS. 11) Accordingly, please provide me with copies of any and all communications related to my efforts to obtain an interview with Superintendent Skipper regarding sexual misconduct, bullying, and other equity matters at BPS. Communications include, but are not limited to, emails, texts, letters, memoranda, faxes, and/or notes. If any relevant communications were done through personal devices, they are public records and therefore they must be produced. 12) Please note that I am submitting this public records request in my capacity as a freelance reporter with no affiliation with any particular media outlet. Thank you. [SPR0909]

On Wednesday night, the climate activists deflated the tires of 43 luxury SUVs around the neighborhood of Beacon Hill. The group took this action to render the large greenhouse gas emitting vehicles unusable, directly preventing the outpouring of emission from the vehicles into our atmosphere which further contribute to climate change and air pollution. Only large, luxury, gas powered SUVs were targeted by the group; no tires were deflated on electric or hybrid vehicles nor any vehicles with handicap signage. The group left leaflets on the cars to inform the owners about why their vehicle was impacted, imploring them to stop using their SUVs and switch to public transportation, biking, or smaller compact electric and hybrid cars. The activists state that SUVs are a dangerous and unnecessary environmental atrocity, especially in city environments where there are sustainable transport options available to everyone. According to a report by the International Council on Clean Transportation (ICCT)(1), SUVs emit an average of 34% more carbon dioxide (CO2) over their lifecycle compared to a typical compact car. Moreover, according to the same organization (2), combustion engine vehicles emit 150% more greenhouse gases over their lifecycle compared to battery operated electric vehicles. The AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety conducted a study(3) on the risk of pedestrian fatalities associated with different types of vehicles, including SUVs and compact cars. The study found that SUVs were 2-3 times more likely to cause pedestrian fatalities than passenger cars in collisions at speeds between 20-39 mph. According to The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) (4), drivers of SUVs are 28% more likely to die in an accident, mostly due to the fact that SUVs are three times as likely to roll over in accidents than standard cars. According to MassDOT transportation records (5), at least 430 people died on public roadways in Massachusetts during 2022, which marks the second consecutive year that the Commonwealth has broken a new record for traffic fatalities. At least 109 of those deaths were individuals on foot, in a wheelchair, or on a bicycle. This problem is only going to get worse, as according to the IEA (6), SUVs made up 27% of the total car sales in 2010, and that skyrocketed to 48% in 2018. Individually owned luxury vehicles are not permissible if we are to reach our climate goals in the state or if we want to keep the residents of the Greater Boston Area safe. The activists took this action in Beacon Hill as it is one of the wealthiest neighborhoods in Boston to own a house. According to an Oxfam report in 2020 (7), the world’s wealthiest 10% were responsible for about 50% of global emissions in 2015 and the top 1% are responsible for as much emissions as the world’s poorest 50%, who will feel the brunt of climate impacts in terms of climate change and pollution despite contributing the least to the cause. The climate crisis is an environmental justice issue and the solutions to the crisis must prioritize marginalized and poor demographics and primarily reduce the emissions from the world’s wealthy. It is not an exaggeration to say that the richest individuals in the world are causing the current and future deaths of the less fortunate and less developed nations and people. Natalia Espinosa Tokuhama Dear Peoples Operations Cabinet Representative, On advisement by your staff, I am writing to request information on the results of the Hybrid Employee Experience Survey. I would like to request the data that was gathered through the anonymous employee survey conducted in late 2022 and early 2023. I am particularly interested in examining the data with regards to how and to what extent the policy affected parents vs single individuals and if there were any particular trends regarding age or gender as to their experience with the hybrid work schedule. Ideally, I would appreciate a summary of the findings to each question, however, as my interest also lies with examining answers to open ended questions and determining how they relate to age and marital status, I would also gladly examine the raw data sets. As this is an academic related request, I will share any findings with whomever you determine most appropriate in your department. Please note, there are no plans for the publishing of this information. It will be supplemental towards the goal of understanding how COVID-19 and subsequent hybrid work models have affected the work/life balance of individuals and whether the effects can vary across genders. Many thanks, Natalia Espinosa Tokuhama

Naomi Martin The Boston Globe Hi, I'm writing to please request: The Boston Public Schools' Department of Early Childhood's Master Implementation List showing which literacy curriculum is in use in each school in Boston Public Schools If this is a spreadsheet please provide it in spreadsheet/ machine-readable format (i.e. Google Sheets/ .csv, .xlsx), not a pdf. That would be in accordance with Mass. G. L. c. 66, § 6A(d): (d) The records access officer shall provide the public records to a requestor by electronic means unless the record is not available in electronic form or the requestor does not have the ability to receive or access the records in a usable electronic form. The records access officer shall, to the extent feasible, provide the public record in the requestor's preferred format or, in the absence of a preferred format, in a searchable, machine readable format. The records access officer shall not be required to create a new public record in order to comply with a request, provided that furnishing a segregable portion of a public record shall not be deemed to be creation of a new record. If the public record requested is available on a public website pursuant to subsection (b) of section 19 of this chapter, section 14C of chapter 7 or any other appropriately indexed and searchable public website, the records access officer may furnish the public record by providing reasonable assistance in locating the requested record on the public website. An electronically produced document submitted to an agency or municipality for use in deliberations by a public body shall be provided in an electronic format at the time of submission. Thank you, Naomi Martin

Marleen Nienhuis Friends of Hiscock Park, Inc Jeff Magee of the BPD Legal Department suggested I request the records below: I am a founding director and treasurer of the recently formed non-profit Friends of Hiscock Park, located at 168 W Newton St in Boston. Earlier this year, we requested a public-research researcher to find out the history of Eldred "Max" Hiscock, the park's namesake. He was a homeless man who lived on the stoop of 159 W Newton St., where he also died in 1970. (He was born in 1907 in Franklin County, ME, and moved to Boston in 1952.) The owners of #159 had helped him obtain Social Security and opened a joint bank account for him from which they paid him $3 each day. In the fall, Max regularly would disappear, picked up under a vagrancy law, to "dry out" in Bridgewater State Hospital where he would also have a daily meal and a warm bed. The attached report (A Brief History of Hiscock Park) fills out many details except for one: No pictures were found of him in records searched so far. Bridgewater State's records are in disarray. Does the BPD have a mug shot or other photo or visual record of Eldred Max Hiscock? I hope so. Thank you.

Cheryl Brown Barton Community College May 31, 2023 Dear Sir/Madam: In compliance with the Jeanne Clery Disclosure of Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act (a.k.a. the “Clery Act”), Barton Community College is required to request annually crime statistics from local law enforcement agencies with jurisdiction over some or all of the property that comprises the institution’s campus, in or on certain off-campus buildings or property owned or controlled by the institution, and on public property within or immediately adjacent to the campus. In compliance with this requirement, we respectfully request that you provide us with crime statistics from the 2022 calendar year for the below listed crimes for the locations specified in the “Geographic Locations” section of this letter. Specifically, we are requesting crime statistics for the following crime categories: •Murder/Non-Negligent Manslaughter • Negligent Manslaughter • Sex Offenses (Forcible Rape, Forcible Sodomy, Sexual Assault with an Object, Forcible Fondling, Incest, and Statutory Rape) • Robbery • Burglary • Aggravated Assault • Motor Vehicle Theft • Arson • Domestic Violence, Dating Violence or Stalking, which are considered crimes under the Clery Act In addition, we need to know if any of the above-listed offenses were categorized as Hate Crimes. We also need to know if there were any incidents of Larceny-Theft; Simple Assault; Intimidation; Destruction/Damage/Vandalism of Property, or other crimes involving bodily injury that were classified as Hate Crimes. If you provide us with statistics regarding Hate Crimes, we also need the category of prejudice for each Hate Crime according to the eight categories for which we are required to report: race, gender, religion, sexual orientation, ethnicity, national origin, gender identity and disability. We also need the statistics for arrests only for the following categories: • Liquor Law Violations • Drug Law Violations • Illegal Weapons Possession • Crime Category Definitions For the crimes of Murder and Non-Negligent Manslaughter, Negligent Manslaughter, Rape, Robbery, Aggravated Assault, Burglary, Motor Vehicle Theft, Arson, Liquor Law Violations, Drug Law Violations, and Illegal Weapons Possession, we are requesting statistics based upon the definitions of those crimes as contained in the Summary Reporting System (SRS) User Manual from the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting Program (UCR). For the crimes of Fondling, Incest, and Statutory Rape, we are requesting statistics based upon the definitions of those crimes as contained in the National Incident-Based Reporting System (NIBRS) User Manual from the FBI’s UCR Program. We are requesting Hate Crime statistics based upon the definitions of those crimes as contained in the Hate Crime Data Collection Guidelines and Training Manual from the FBI’s UCR Program We are also requesting separate statistics for any incidents reported to your agency that involve Domestic Violence, Dating Violence or Stalking, which are considered crimes under the Clery Act and are defined as follows for statistical reporting purposes: • Domestic Violence: 1. A felony or misdemeanor crime of violence committed— a. By a current or former spouse or intimate partner of the victim; b. By a person with whom the victim shares a child in common’ c. By a person who is cohabitating with, or has cohabitated with, the victim as a spouse or intimate partner; d. By a person similarly situated to a spouse of the victim under the domestic or family violence laws of the jurisdiction in which the crime of violence occurred; or e. By any other person against an adult or youth victim who is protected from that person’s acts under the domestic or family violence laws of the jurisdiction in which the crime of violence occurred. • Dating violence: Violence committed by a person who is or h

BAT/POLICE REPORTS Marco Crespo Dear officer, As per email below, I did not deliver one of the shipments from my Amazon order at my hotel (Hotel Commonwealth located at 500 Commonwealth Ave in Boston. This is the only package the hotel front desk said they did not receive while Amazon is saying they did deliver the package. In order to get a refund, Amazon is asking for a police report on that matter. Not sure what investigation would be required in this sense but I am happy to help in any way I can. The items missing are: - garmin chest band - garmin screen protectors Thanks, Marco (+55 ) —— email from Amazon —— Hello, We’re sorry to hear that you haven’t received your items from order # . It's very important to us that our customers receive the products they purchase from Amazon. We appreciate your business and regret that these items haven't been delivered to you. Items that aren't received are inconvenient for you and costly for Amazon. Based on the outcome of our investigations, we believe the package was delivered to the correct address. In particular we have considered information from our records, as follows which show the item was delivered: - Information collected at the point of delivery. - The package weight and reported condition upon delivery. You may wish to contact your local police authorities to pursue this matter further. If the issue isn't resolved after contacting local law enforcement please contact us back during the business hours of the related police department with a Police Report number, a link to access your Police Report, or a PDF/Image file of the Police Report. There are multiple ways to file a Police Report. Check with your local authorities for ways to file a report. In order for us to validate your Police Report, it must be in a "Complete/Closed" state, be reported in the local jurisdiction (city, county, municipal) in which the package was reported delivered, and include the following: - The delivery address regarding this incident. - The items were delivered according to the carrier tracking. - The report was created for stolen items/theft/larceny/incorrect delivery or similar crime. - The date the report was created. - The name of the police department. - If the Police Report was created over the phone: The name and badge number of the reporting officer. We’re unable to accept Police Reports that are in “pending” or any other incomplete status, as well as reports not filed in the local jurisdiction in which the package was reported as delivered. The Police Report must be filed before 10 July 2023 to be considered for review. Only one Police Report is needed for all orders that are part of the same shipment. A separate Police Report is needed for orders delivered in different shipments. To assist in obtaining a Police Report, we recommend that you provide a copy of this email to the police to help explain what has happened. We will happily cooperate with the police as part of any investigation. Thank you for your understanding. We'd appreciate your feedback. Please use the buttons below to vote about your experience today. Best regards, Reeddhiman G Amazon.com

The timeframe for this request spans from January 1, 2022, to the present date, June 4, 2023. The paramount objective of this request is to assure the tribal community directly impacted by the Long Island Bridge project. By delving into Mayor Michelle Wu's communication records, I aim to glean insights into the decision-making process, anticipated consequences, and the extent of engagement between the city administration and tribal representatives. Unearthing these emails will enable a comprehensive understanding of the intricate dynamics and considerations that underpin the permitting process. By meticulously analyzing the content and context of these communications, I can provide the public with a nuanced perspective on the city's unwavering commitment to engaging with the tribal community and duly addressing their concerns and interests. To ensure seamless access and compatibility, I respectfully request that the provided documents be furnished in the widely compatible PDF format. If the original documents exist in alternative formats, such as Outlook .pst files, I kindly request their conversion to PDF before dissemination. Furthermore, I would greatly appreciate being notified in advance of any potential costs associated with fulfilling this request. Kindly apprise me of any applicable fees, charges, or estimated total expenses, if any, prior to proceeding with the request. If fees are involved, I kindly request an itemized breakdown to facilitate clear understanding. For the sake of expediency and efficiency, I kindly request that the requested documents be shared electronically, either via email or through a secure online portal. Should you require any elucidation or have any inquiries pertaining to this request, please do not hesitate to reach out to me. Thank you for your invaluable attention to this matter. I eagerly anticipate a prompt response within the legally mandated timeframe.

We want to understand the full scope of your efforts, not just the portions funded by the grant, if possible. Here is the information we have been given by BJA based on what you submitted: Sum of SAKs inventoried: 1,701 Sum of SAKs sent for testing: 0 Sum of CODIS hits: 0 Sum of victims contacted: 3 Sum of investigations opened: 2 Sum of cases charged: 2 Sum of convictions, including plea bargains: 0 Based on some of the media coverage I’ve seen of your SAK program, I believe several of these stats are likely undercounts. Can you please provide us with accurate totals for each of these lines? Also, if you have any documentation regarding these stats, or other outcomes from your grant, that you think it would be helpful for us to see, feel free to provide it as well. Additionally, we have a few questions regarding your grant program we are hoping you can answer. Which law enforcement agencies provided kits that were tested as a part of this grant? Mary Skipper, Superintendent Bruce C. Bolling Municipal Building 2300 Washington Street, 5th Floor Roxbury, Massachusetts 02119 June 20, 2023 Dear Jeremiah E. Burke High School Community, I am writing to inform you that the Boston Police Department is investigating the fraudulent enrollment of an adult woman who used falsified identification and paperwork to register as a student this academic year. This individual has been discharged and is being ordered to stay away from Boston Public Schools (BPS) facilities. At various points during the 2022-2023 school year, this individual attended the Jeremiah E. Burke High School, Brighton High School, and English High School utilizing the student transfer process and enrolling under multiple pseudonyms. Last week a BPS staff member observed irregularities in the paperwork on file and reported it to District leadership, who immediately contacted Boston Police. While the investigation is in its early stages and remains ongoing, school officials have not identified any incidents of harm to students or staff. At this time families of students who may have interacted with this individual are being contacted directly by school staff and investigators. We will provide additional updates if relevant information becomes available through the investigation. Mary Skipper Superintendent Boston Public Schools

BAT/POLICE REPORTS Adriana Jean Louis MA DPH To Whom it May Concern: The Massachusetts Department of Public Health (“Department”) conducts investigations of all pregnancy-associated deaths in Massachusetts, which include any death of a woman while pregnant or within one year of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of cause. The Department conducts these investigations pursuant to a study, the Pregnancy-associated Mortality and Morbidity Review Study, that is authorized by the Commissioner of Public Health under M.G.L. c. 111, §24A. We are requesting that you provide a copy of any records described below. This study has been ongoing since 1997 when the Commissioner of Public Health appointed a Maternal Mortality and Morbidity Review Committee (MMMRC) to review maternal deaths, study the incidence of pregnancy complications, and make recommendations to improve maternal outcomes and prevent mortality. The work of the committee is protected under M.G.L. c. 111, §24A, which assures the confidentiality of all records and other information collected as part of an investigation. The committee consists of obstetricians, certified nurse midwives, maternal fetal medicine specialists, neonatologists, and pathologists who investigate cases of maternal mortality and make recommendations to the Department. In order to further the work of the Committee, the Department is requesting that you provide a copy of all police reports for Sermonia Roscoe (DOB: & DOD: 09/25/2020) including those associated with her death in Boston, MA. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me by email or phone. Thank you for your attention to this matter, Adriana Jean Louis

Schools - Legal Jessica Martinez Lawyers for Civil Rights This letter constitutes a request under the Public Records Law, G. L. c. 66, §10, for public records in the custody of Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (“DESE”) and the City of Boston. As used in this request, “record(s)” is defined as in the Public Records Law. “School(s)” refers to all Boston public schools including traditional district schools, exam schools, pilot schools, Horace Mann charter schools, innovation schools, schools with international baccalaureate programs, and dual language schools. “Teacher(s) refers to educators employed by Boston Public Schools (“BPS”) regardless of the type of contract or subject matter specialty. “Non-teaching staff” refers to all individuals employed in a Boston public school in any other role but that of educator, such as administrators. “Department(s)” refers to departments within BPS as a government entity. Unless otherwise specified, the period for which records are requested is August 1, 2018, to the present. I hereby request copies of the following documents: 1. All records indicating or reflecting the total number of current BPS teachers and non-teaching staff employed at a Boston public school disaggregated by race, gender, and school. 2. All records indicating or reflecting the total number of BPS teachers and non-teaching staff employed at a Boston public school who have been separated in the past five years, disaggregated by gender, race, and school (separated includes those who were terminated, retired, and/or resigned). 3. All records indicating or reflecting the employees captured in Request Number 2 that have been placed on administrative leave at any time in their employment prior to separation, disaggregated by gender, race, and school 4. All records indicating or reflecting the total number of BPS employees (i.e. those employees not working in a Boston public schools and therefore not captured in response to Requests 1-3), disaggregated by BPS department, gender, and race. 5. All records indicating or reflecting the number of BPS employees (i.e. those employees not working in a Boston public schools and therefore not captured in response to Requests 1-3) who have been separated in the past five years, disaggregated by BPS department, gender, and race (separated includes those who were terminated, retired, and/or resigned). 6. All records indicating or reflecting employees captured in Request Number 5 that have been placed on administrative leave prior to separation, disaggregated by gender, race, and school.

BTD Michael Weingarten At the Mayor’s June 22 Back Bay/Beacon Hill Neighborhood Meeting, Jascha Franklin- Hodge, Boston’s Chief of Streets, told one of my neighbors (Ali Foley) that the City had prepared data-based analyses/evaluations of pedestrian, bicycle and vehicular traffic at key intersections in Back Bay, leading to its recently announced decision to create dedicated bicycle lanes on Boylston, Berkeley and the A/B Beacon block while removing parking spaces to make room for these lanes. However, he has refused to provide me with copies of his work, saying that he would “respond in more detail when I’m able.” My concern is that this promised “respon[se] in more detail” will only come at the 11th hour just before construction begins and it is too late to affect the City’s plans. Accordingly, I request electronic copies of the following: 1. Any studies, analyses, evaluations, and communications concerning Back Bay bike lanes over the past 12 months, including but not limited to emails, memos, and presentations sent, prepared, or received by Franklin-Hodge or his team members (collectively, “work”). 2. In addition to work related to implementing an optimal Back Bay bike plan, any work related to the impact of the bike lane plans on abutters, traffic congestion, safety, the ability to find parking spaces, and pollution. 3. Supporting data analyses that the City used as inputs for its plans. Including Excel files. 4.Studies or database information regarding vehicular/bike/pedestrian accident incidence on key Back Bay Intersections and along the A/B Beacon block. 5. Post- 2017 Back Bay parking meter capacity utilization studies. [I already have a copy of the City’s 2017 presentations to the Back Bay community.] 6. Analyses of the cost of the City’s bike lane construction plans and the prospective reduction in parking meter fees. 7. Analyses of the financial impact of the City’s plans on reduced abutter property valuations and property taxes. I do not need intersection traffic counts at this time, since BTD has provided me with counts it commissioned in October 2022. For earlier reports, I have access to the ScerIS ETCETERA database. Rather I need to see any analyses performed by City traffic engineers using this information. If any supporting analyses were created in Excel workbooks, my ability to understand them will require access to the underlying formulas – particularly if the workbooks involve multiple worksheets or contains external cell references. Accordingly, I ask that I receive any Excel files in read-only .xlxs format. Given that Franklin- Hodge has stated that he plans to begin bike lane construction this fall, this records request is time sensitive. [SPR23/1728]

OPC Dan Conley Mintz I represent Daniel J. Wendler, a 3rd year resident physician at Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH). On May 17, 2023 my client suffered a serious mental health breakdown during which he called Boston 911 at 6:57:41 PM and spoke to the operator for approximately 9 minutes. It is my understanding that he informed the operator that he was in possession of a rifle and either wanted to turn it in or have the police take it from him. Rather than wait for the police to arrive at his North End apartment, my client walked to the MGH Emergency Room carrying the rifle. The rifle was unloaded, he was not brandishing it or menacing anyone, and he gave up the firearm when asked to do so by an MGH Security Officer. My client’s colleagues immediately admitted him to the Emergency Room and later that evening was he committed for psychiatric care under MGL C. 123, s. 12. The Boston Police took possession of the rifle and filed an incident report (# 232038625). The Boston Police did not arrest my client that evening, but rather sought a complaint and summons arraignment. My client is scheduled for arraignment for unlawfully carrying a firearm on July 27, 2023 in the Boston Municipal Court-Central Division. My request for information is as follows: 1. A copy of the audio recording of my client’s call to Boston-911 made from his cellphone ( ) on May 17, 2023 at 6:57:41 that lasted for approximately 9 minutes; and 2. A copy of the report of the examination of the rifle seized by Boston Police officers on May 17, 2023 at or near the MGH Emergency Room and examined by Boston Police Ballistics Unit. Thank you for your assistance in this matter and please let me know if I can provide any further information. Best, Dan C Daniel F. Conley Special Counsel

If I can provide any clarification that will help expedite your attention to our request, please contact me at or @hearst.com. Thank you, Brittany Johnson [381 Old Colony]
